title: U.S. Blacklists Entities, Vessels for Allegedly Delivering Venezuelan Oil to Cuba
text:
The U.S. has blacklisted four entities and four related vessels for allegedly transporting oil from Venezuela to Cuba. Venezuela's President, Nicolás Maduro, is shown above.

The U.S. imposed more sanctions targeting Venezuela’s oil sector, blacklisting four entities and four related vessels for allegedly transporting oil from Venezuela to Cuba, the Treasury said on Tuesday.

The designations come after the U.S. blacklisted state-owned oil company Petróleos de Venezuela SA, an important revenue generator for the country, in January, in a move to cripple Nicolás Maduro’s government and empower opposition leader Juan Guaidó.

“Maduro’s Cuban benefactors provide a lifeline to the regime and enable its repressive security and intelligence apparatus,” Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Tuesday.

The Treasury levied sanctions on Cyprus-based Caroil Transport Marine Ltd., which operates three vessels that the Treasury alleged recently delivered Venezuelan petroleum products to Cuba as part of an arrangement involving PdVSA, Cuba’s state-run oil import-and-export company Cubametales and Cuban officials. The Treasury also blacklisted two Panama-based companies that are the registered owners of two of the vessels operated by Caroil Transport Marine. The U.S. in July blacklisted Cubametales for its continued importation of oil from Venezuela. A representative for Caroil Transport Marine didn’t immediately provide a comment. Another Panamanian company that owns a crude oil tanker that allegedly delivered Venezuelan oil to Cuba recently was also blacklisted by the Treasury. The Treasury also removed sanctions on two Liberian entities and their vessels in recognition of a change of behavior, including discontinuing business and charter with Cubametales and adopting sanctions compliance measures, the department said. Write to Mengqi Sun at mengqi.sun@wsj.com
